importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period spanning from 2023 to 2025 shows a recurring pattern of anti-immigrant protests in Ireland, particularly after incidents involving asylum seekers or immigration-related crimes.

keyTakeAways: Anti-immigrant protests in Dublin on October 21, 2025, turned violent after allegations of a sexual assault on a 10-year-old girl by a man linked to the Citywest Hotel, which hosts asylum seekers.
The protester group used fireworks, bottles, and signs such as 'Irish lives matter' and 'Get them out!' to target asylum seekers and law enforcement.
A police van was set on fire, and officers used pepper spray to disperse protesters near the Citywest Hotel.
The man accused of the assault is reported to be an asylum seeker who requested a Romanian interpreter in court; police have not confirmed his ethnicity.
The girl reportedly absconded during a trip and was under state care at the time of the incident.
Ireland's Minister for Justice Jim O’Callaghan condemned the 'weaponisation of a crime' and pledged a 'forceful response'.
Prime Minister Micheal Martin described the events as 'extremely serious and very, very grave'.
This incident follows a similar 2023 riot in Dublin after a knife attack on children, where a man from Algeria was identified as the suspect and a far-right mob attacked police and vehicles.

Anti-immigration sentiment has risen in both Ireland and Northern Ireland, with protests in Ballymena in June 2024 involving two Romanian boys arrested on suspicion of assault, leading to armed rioters attacking police and setting fires.
Despite Ireland having no far-right MPs, anti-immigrant unrest has grown, showing a societal and political shift towards xenophobic mobilization in response to immigration-related incidents.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 21, 2025, anti-immigrant protesters in southwest Dublin clashed violently with police after allegations of a sexual assault on a 10-year-old girl by a man linked to the Citywest Hotel, which houses asylum seekers. Protesters threw bottles, launched fireworks, and carried signs such as 'Irish lives matter' and 'Get them out!', while a police van was set on fire. The accused man, described as an asylum seeker who requested a Romanian interpreter, has not been confirmed in ethnicity. The incident follows a similar 2023 riot in Dublin after a knife attack on children, with a suspect from Algeria, and earlier unrest in Ballymena, Northern Ireland, where two Romanian boys were arrested on suspicion of assault. Despite Ireland having no far-right MPs, rising anti-immigration sentiment has led to repeated violent protests, illustrating a broader societal shift in response to immigration-related crimes.
